top_comment.text:
Anyone notice that in the beginning when they were flipping the pages, 
Superman was hiding behind a wall holding a gun? Why does superman need a 
gun?﻿
top_comment.author: Drinks Made Easy

comments.text:
That was the final issue of All-Star Superman. That particular scene was a 
reinterpreted moment wherein Lex Luthor had copied Superman's powers (by 
copying a serum Superman himself had made for Lois earlier), overloaded 
Superman's cells with solar radiation through unknown methods (leading to 
cell death that threw Superman's power into severe flux), and enlisted the 
help of Solaris the Tyrant Sun (who blocked out and "poisoned" the Sun and 
bathed the Earth in red sunlight to weaken Superman. Unfortunately for 
Solaris, Superman had a suit that maintained his strength long enough to 
win the fight). The gun is a Gravity Gun (yes, it is capitalized), which, 
as you would guess, amplifies the gravitic effects on the target. I'm not 
going to spoil how well it works, but the fight (and comic as a whole) is 
pretty darn awesome.

The good Superman stories don't need Kryptonite; in fact, All-Star makes 
him *immune* to green Kryptonite, but still manages to have a very engaging 
story with a lot of great conflict. I highly recommend it, since it was the 
first Superman comic I actually liked.
comments.author: RikoZerame

comments.text:
+Cartman Not the worst conclusion, but there's one problem with it:

Unless they decide to reboot his powers or go for drama that nobody will 
buy, no official story will ever have the Hulk die. Just like SCP-682 (
http://www.scp-wiki.net/scp-682) and Doomsday, the Hulk exists as something 
that cannot be stopped permanently, or even for a reasonably long 
time. Thus, if Superman punched the Hulk, the latter would either Hulk out 
at the last moment with enough strength to resist the punch, someone would 
save the Hulk (i.e. the Sentry, Thor...someone equally overpowered), or the 
writers would throw physics out the window like Spider-man threw Wolverine 
and have the Hulk regenerate from non-existence. "His rage will never die" 
after all.

It would be fun to see how they saved him, though, not to mention just the 
crossover in general.
comments.author: RikoZerame

However I think you missed a point when you talked about Superman eating 
all those Big Macs. If you read the comics or if you have any info on 
Superman then you would have known that Superman actually do not require

a nuclear reactor and for chain reaction Superman uses Sun rays I don't 
know specifically which rays. But yeah consistent nuclear explosions would

comments.author: kapilesh14

comments.text:
Since this is the channel that digs deep into silly things, I'm gonna dig 
deep into this (presumably) not-so-serious comment:

First, Superman would need those billions of big-Macs to actually deliver 
the punch, and I think buying so many big macs would not only cost very 
much, but also be very very hard to do. If one big mac would weigh 100 
grams, then you'd need ~8.2*10^9 kg of meat. According to a quick google 
search, all cattle combined at the moment has a biomass of 5.2*10^11kg. If 
you'd assume you can productively use half the weight of the cow for 
burgers, you'd need 1 in every 50 cows in the WORLD, just to make the 
burgers for a single superman punch.

Then also, regardless of the food you'd give superman, you'd probably kill 
loads of people in the process. Feeding superman such a huge part of the 
current amount of food on this planet would surely cause the food stocks of 
basically everywhere close to the testing site to be completely empty, 
which means the less wealthy probably wouldn't be able to get access to 
food.

Now, if these didn't convince you this wouldn't be a good idea even if 
superman were real, there's another problem. You can't study the effects of 
nuclear fission by simply detonating an atomic bomb, because the process is 
way too uncontrolled to gather any data, and any data you'd gather would be 
destroyed immediately. You can't transfer the data to another device 
either, since the electromagnetic waves emitted by the bomb would make it 
impossible to distinguish the signals that are being sent. The same applies 
to superman punching with this much energy: the explosion caused by it is 
way too uncontrolled to ever gather any useful data from, except for being 
able to answer the question "when is humankind going to blow itself up".
comments.author: joeytje50

comments.text:
+Idazmi7
Maybe thats why its not really a big explosion.  "Big Bang" is something of 
a misnomer, rather, it is an expansion of space/time.  Of course, it starts 
off at the speed of light, and so 'explosion' is a fairly good description, 
but technically it doesnt really fit.
So what really is it?
Concider that the strong nuclear force and gravity are 'negative' forces, 
whilst the weak nuclear force and electromagnatism are 'positive' forces.  
Scientists have been figuring this out for quite a whie, and basically it 
turns out that the universe balances out to zero.  If you stood outside of 
the universe, the whole of space would be one pinprick, with all time in 
one blink, and it would be a tiny blur of nothing.  Of course from inside 
the universe, we see what we see.

This brings us to the formation of the protein.
This did not happen during the 'Big Bang', but much much later, after stars 
had been born and died, heavy elements produced in supernova, planets 
formed and developed, and eventually warmed by our sun, after everything 
had calmed down.

comments.text:
+Cool to the Facts
I'm going to give you an example of why your interpretation of the huge 
numbers involved in that randomness is WAY off.
We're going to flip coins, and we want to throw 10 heads on 10 coins to 
simulate the formation of a simple protein (Obviously you would be talking 
of throusands of heads/coins, but you get the idea).  So how much coin 
throwing does this take?
Method 1)  Throw all 10 coins, if they dont all come up heads, then start 
again.  Its 1 in 1024 throws x10 coins = 10240 to get all heads.  This is 
what you are suggesting, and it is NOT how nature works.
Method 2)  Throw 10 coins, keep the heads, re-throw the tails and repeat.  
In this method, it takes only about 19-20 throws to get 10 heads on 10 
coins, and this is how nature works, it keeps the successes and moves on.

So you see, with around 14 billion years and a universe to play with, the 
formation of protein is not just likely, its a certainty.

comments.text:
well, once you understand that the laws of physics there could be 
completely different. then you have to understand that what comprises a 
human inherently has to be different. of course they can still exist, but 
possibly in a different form. they may have similar compositions but they 
may behave differently. in fact if simple observations can be believed the 
durability of humans in the DC or Marvel universe for that matter, have to 
A: either be composed of stronger more durable matter considering that 
people like batman get tossed around and sometimes launched by serious 
blows that would easily kill even the strongest humans in our universe. or 
B: matter itself is comprised of something different, likely with 
significantly less mass. (thus accounting for the speed at which they 
traverse the galaxy in some cases) in fact if this is to be believed that 
mass in their universe is significantly less and that all objects are as a 
result less dense it is within the realm of posiblility that Superman is 
identical to that of a human in our universe, whos composition is so much 
more contained mass compared to whole galaxies of their universe that he 
ends up god like.  . . . kryptonians may be humans as we know them, as 
opposed to the humans of that universe! or im just babbling bull shit in 
order to push the point that ultimately, by simply being another universe 
ANYTHING is possible and likely everything we assume based on our universes 
laws could be entirely wrong there.

comments.text:
+labib
Well, actually there are a lot of factors in "speed" to analyze before 
saying A is faster than B because A can reach X speed higher than B, speed 
isn't just an unilateral factor, there are a lot of factors of speed.

Factors like: Flight speed, limb's movement speed, consecutive movements 
rate speed, reaction speed and max speed limit and acceleration rate for 
limbs and flight speed.

The factor you mentioned is probably Max achievable flight speed or flight 
speed limit.

But as there are many other speed related factors, somebody's max speed 
might not be usable or might be impractical for battle depending on several 
factors, like acceleration rate, desaceleration rate, maneuverability, and 
reaction time.

And, I might be wrong, but for what I have seen and what I know about both 
characters, I would arguably say in overall that while Superman is  capable 
of achieving higher speeds while flying large distances through outer 
space, Goku has consistently shown to be a much faster figther, capable of 
accelarating, desacelerating, changing directions, reacting, punching, 
kicking, blocking and dodging at faster rate than Superman, all of which 
traduce into having better ofensive and defensive skills which derive from 
the right aplication of his powers through his martial arts mastery.

top_comment.text:
According to this video, if Superman punched you at 99% of the speed of 
light, not only would the city you were standing in be vaporized, but he 
would burn 45.4*10^13 calories doing it.
I assume that Superman gets some of his energy from our yellow sun. 
According to Wikipedia peak sunlight gives 1367 watts per m^2 and the 
average adult male human has a surface area of 1.9m^2. Only one half of his 
body could face the sun at a time, and assuming 12 hours exposure per day, 
gives us 2.5*10^9 calories at best per year.
According to some calculations the planet can produce 10.95*10^15 calories 
per year in total. The amount from the sun is negligible at this point.
Assuming Superman had a 100% efficient metabolism, Superman punching 
something as hard as he could one time would consume 0.415% of all the 
energy the sun and earth could deliver to him in total if everyone else on 
the plant stopped eating. If he did this once a day starting Jan 1st, he 
would starve sometime before August 30 (and everyone else would have 
starved sometime before Martin Luther King’s Day.)﻿

comments.text:
+Manpacattack I always have to question people who talk about him being 
done poorly, because they always seem to refer back to the same things - 
crappy video games or movies, vague recollections of comics without any 
specific references, and the cliche "he always wins" argument that applies 
to every single other hero. It's not like Batman ever struggles with any of 
his guys after his first encounter (sometimes not even then).  

Jack Kirby introducing the whole Fourth World/New Gods mythos through his 
Superman/Jimmy Olsen series in the 70s, John Byrne's redefining of the 
character in the 1980s during the Crisis on Infinite Earths era, Dan 
Jurgen's main series in the 1990s (beyond just the Death/Return of 
Superman), Grant Morrison's handling of Superman and others in the 90s 
relaunch of JLA (still the best version of that team ever written). And 
then the more recent stand-alone stories like Superman: Birthright, Red 
Son, All-Star Superman, Earth 2, Kingdom Come. All of these various runs 
and stand-alone short series over the years present plenty of great writing 
of the character, I think certainly equal to anything Batman's gotten - and 
more than many other DC A-listers.

and again I state that's the only relatable thing about him. people usually 
like a comic character because they can relate to that person in numerous 
ways. Admittedly sometimes it only takes the one, but for most people they 
have to feel some kind of connection to the character's 
personality/struggles. In the case of superman not many people can make 
that happen. I'm not saying he's a horrible character and should never have 
existed, but simply stating why a lot of people don't tend to like him.

Another reason people read comics is to see how the hero overcomes the 
peril of the situation they've been put in, and knowing that they can be 
killed if they don't.  Obviously we know they're going to win in the end, 
but with most superheroes there's a real possibility they won't for some 
reason. No one feels like that could happen with superman. If what I was 
told in another discussion is true, he fought someone on a planet littered 
with kryptonite and at least one red sun, managed to punch the guy clean 
through it, and carry on like it was nothing. Again, IF that's true, 
there's just no way the reader/viewer can genuinely feel his life is in 
danger. I realize he, like most superheroes, cares more about the innocent 
people involved then his own safety, but they're almost never in any real 
danger either. That's simply my experience with the character and his lore.

comments.text:
+Manpacattack Actually Superman does have burdens, he always has to 
constantly monitor his strength, and how much he puts out. He has to make 
sure that he never loses focus or else a single touch will turn someone 
into dust(Essentially.) With the burden of knowing that he can, at any 
moment, with a touch of a finger kill someone it makes him worry all the 
time.

Superman has also went through many depressing stages of his life. In 
Superman: Grounded, we explore his mind, it is a battle that is raging on 
in his mind, whether or not the world even NEEDS Superman. He has to go on 
a journey and discover whether or not he is truly needed. 

Superman may not seem like someone that has a lot of depth to him, but he 
truly does have some depth to him. And he does shoulder his own burdens. 

Superman has been rivaled by many. Doomsday actually KILLED Superman, he 
didn't wind him, didn't knock him out, he actually killed Superman. The 
only people that can take on Superman are people with equal or greater 
strength than him, with magic, or Kryptonite. Magic isn't rare in the DC 
Universe, so a very powerful Magician can take on Superman and most likely 
Win. And Captain Marvel can take on Superman and win. 

There is no "bullshit" to some people's victories against the Man Of Steel 
himself. There are many valid losses to Superman and each either plays 
directly to his real weaknesses or the person is equal or greater in 
strength. Darkseid comes to mind.

There are a lot of flaws with this video, in respect to Superman's power. 
But I'll point out the biggest one, he can not punch ANYWHERE near the 
speed of light, while standing. His travel speed is unimaginably more 
faster than his combat speed, which it more comparable to machine gun fire 
speed. One of Superman's greatest feats and abilities is something he stole 
from the flash, his "infinite mass punch", in which he spends time, prior, 
building travel momentum, until he essentially travels through you, at 
light speed, with his fist at the front.(not saying it makes scientific 
sense, just saying what's present in the comics) I still like the video, as 
it kinda gives you an idea of what one of his more powerful techniques 
would do to someone, but saying it's something he can to at any given 
moment isn't accurate at all. 
But, in the end, you're really not going to be any less dead, getting hit 
by Supe's fist, on nearly any occasion.﻿

comments.text:
+Samuel Weinstein "Not the surrounding area; he'd destroy whatever's 
nearby."

The "surrounding area" is not "the world".  Superman causes massive 
collateral damage all the time, knocking over buildings and destroying 
entire neighborhoods.

But if it means so much to you. think long and hard on the best conceivable 
armour Batman can use, then calculate the minimum amount of Newtonian Force 
necessary to put him into a coma in spite of that armor from one 
application of blunt force trauma.  Superman has calculated that in less 
than a 1000th of a second and has delivered it to Batman faster than the 
Bat can either perceive or react.  

It takes a fair amount of PIS for Batman to be conscious one second after 
the fight begins.
comments.author: Infinite Sheldon

comments.text: Not the surrounding area; he'd destroy whatever's nearby.

speed, however. He wouldn't risk destroying the world."

the speed of light.

comments.text:
+Infinite Sheldon
Superman wouldn't be able to throw a punch at that speed, however. He 
wouldn't risk destroying the world.
comments.author: Samuel Weinstein

comments.text:
+Samuel Weinstein "No matter how much he reads, he still isn't as clever as 
Batman, nor will he have the same ability to think on his feet."

Superman moves at relativistic speeds and possesses nanosecond reaction 
time.  For every second that passes, Superman has the equivalent of at 
least one century to think and respond to anything Batman does.  You're 
drinking the PIS if you think Batman can think on his feet better than 
Superman.

"He might be human, but he's still smarter."

See above.  Superman memorized the sum total of human medical information 
in five minutes and then invented a new medical treatment.  Batman is a 
pocket calculator and Superman is a supercomputer.  That's the difference 
between their minds.  You'd have to seriously nerf Superman to think a 
human can be smarter.

"all it would take is one smear-campaign as Bruce Wayne to completely 
discredit Superman and reveal his identity."

The world likes Superman more than Batman, the people have a lower opinion 
of Bruce Wayne than Clark Kent, and Superman is romantically involved with 
a Pulitzer Prize winning journalist.  Superman can launch a smear campaign 
against the Bat far more effectively than vice versa.  

"Also, they wouldn't have the same preparation  time. Batman would have 
calculated that down to a tee, because he's a meticulous planner who 
wouldn't leave things up to a "fair fight"."

See "relativistic speeds" and "nanosecond reaction time".  No amount of 
prep time can account for what Superman can accomplish within a single 
second.  One second is one century of prep time for Superman, and that's 
after the fight begins.

"Batman might even get the backing of VILLAINS, given as he mostly fights 
crime on a municipal level (Gotham) and consequentially has less enemies."

This video shows what happens to a city when Superman throws a single punch 
and you propose having multiple persons punching each other with similar 
effect?  So Batman's solution is to inadvertently trigger Nuclear Winter 
and wipe out all human life on Earth.  Good jorb, Bats, you're still dead 
(probably vaporized at ground zero as a bystander) and Superman is still 
standing.  It would take a fair amount of Plot Armour for the end result to 
be anything different.

""Something to counter it" may not exist, canonically speaking. You can't 
just make shit up and use it in a debate, lol."

Superman's powers and abilities counter everything Batman does.  The 
Fortress of Solitude is 0.13 seconds away from Superman and it is better 
stocked than the Batcave.

Batman's only win condition is for Superman to do absolutely nothing in 
response to anything. You could use the same argument for a humble cabbage 
salesman beating Batman in a fight. As I've said, it takes a fair amount of 
PIS and Plot Armour for the Bat to last a single second against Superman.
comments.author: Infinite Sheldon

comments.text:
+karl prankard I'll keep this short since trying to explain this is getting 
tedious.

An alien species with a better grasp or different understanding of physics 
may have technology that would allow humans to move faster than light. This 
we agree on. However, an alien species given special powers by solar 
exposure (Kryptonians) may, by using their knowledge of how physics can be 
manipulated, use the laws of physics against physics themselves. For 
example, perhaps by vibrating his body until his molecular bonds weaken as 
well as flying full speed allows Superman to travel faster than light speed 
because he is essentially negating his own mass by turning his body 
slightly intangible thus negating that pesky, "nothing with mass can go 
beyond light speed."  It would also explain why it was stated in the issue 
where he IMP'd the Shadow Moon that he "only works this hard when traveling 
faster than light speed but this time he wants to stay just under."

Maybe that's it. The elusive answer to satisfy the laws of physics are 
immutable fans. Superman can travel up to light speed which increases his 
mass infinitely just like the scientist all say. However, when he reaches 
light speed he goes slightly intangible which allows him to fly even faster 
because he's negating his own mass. Which is also why he doesn't do it 
unless he has to, it's a lot of work to get to that point because he's 
doing two incredible things at once....

I can live with that explanation.

mor·tal  [mawr-tl] 
adjective
1.

means: subject to death, destined to die, mortal: quid in his mortale et

top_comment.text:
Hey Vsauce3! It has been awhile since you answered some good questions. So 
I thought I would ask you something that has been on my mind. This is 
mostly focused on the game "Mortal Kombat". There is a fatality that has me 
rather stumped. A classic Fatality from the character Sub-zero depicts him 
actually tearing another persons head off with the spine still attached.

The thing is. How much for force would it require to tear another persons 
head off? Would it even be possible to have the spine remain intact when so 
much force is being applied? This is a question I think should be answered 
for all the gaming geeks out there, like myself.﻿
top_comment.author: salsav91

comments.text:
+marveluniverseboom makes sence, you deserve some likes for that,
thanks for the explanation
comments.author: The Nice Narval

comments.text:
The spine is attached to the skull ( to your brain stem/medulla) so when 
Sub-Zero pulls the opposing fighters' head off, the spine would naturally 
follow since ya'know it's attached.

Well, since the force to cut a another human's head off is around 250 
newtons, I'd assume to RIP a person's head off of their body would be 540 
newtons cince the skull/spine is pretty tight on there with the muscle and 
skin covering and around the skull/spine.

As for your question on whether the spine should remain intact given the 
amount of force, I would say it would. You see, when Sub-Zero pulls the 
head off the opposing fighters' body, it would be moving quite fast so it 
probably wouldn't break.

It's similiar to the tablecloth trick, where you pull the tablecloth out 
under the dishes on top and have them remain intact. In this case, Sub-Zero 
pulls the head off, leaving the body intact and dropping to the floor.
comments.author: marveluniverseboom

+RoboticRedstone Since I'm slowly but surely beginning to think of you as 
somewhat of a lost cause, I am now leaving you with my very last attempt to 
make you see what actually caused you to confuse 'Google' and 'googol'. 
Hint: it's got to do with grammar:
mrpxi wrote, "One google". Considering 'Google' is spelled with a capital G 
and there's no comma in the sentence (i.e. "One, Google"), this makes 
anyone with basic English skills assume mrpxi meant 'googol', the number 
(as in "One googol.").

Another light-hearted example of this kind of grammatical confusion:
"Let's eat, grandpa!" vs.
"Let's eat grandpa!"

....Do you finally see what happened here? If not, you need professional 
help. I recommend grammar lessions and maybe also therapy sessions along 
the lines of "Your argument is invalid, deal with it!".

need it...

top_comment.text:
In the Scientific law of BioGenesis we can read that life only comes from 
existing life.. a very hot, sterile and wet rock with no organic matter on 
it.. life coming there from doesn't make much sense according to what 
science has shown us through the law of BioGenesis which has never been 
overcome. Scientist have only been able to create elements found in life, 
not been able to create life..﻿
top_comment.author: Pure Education

comments.text:
Pasteur stated the law of biogenesis to dispel the erroneous contention at 
the time that life could spontaneously appear from nonliving matter all the 
time. Farmers with grain sometimes thought that mice magically sprung from 
the stores themselves, things of that nature. Abiogenesis, life springing 
from nonliving matter, seems to have happened at least once on earth 
because, well, here we all are. When you trace our lineage back far enough, 
all life on earth derived from primitive single-celled organisms. 
Abiogenesis as a basis for life on earth is a theory in so far as we have 
not replicated the circumstances to make life from non-life, yet! I think 
we eventually will.

So it comes down to what you think is more plausible, as a scientist. That 
a few billion years of chemical mixes, variations in heat, cold, and 
weather on a barren world eventually got amino acids to form into some kind 
of super primitive lifeform, or that a deity (for no reason at all) created 
something new for fun or whimsy. Why does the second one seem so tempting 
to you?

comments.author: Jan Jappie Ukelele

comments.text:
+AmateurYoutuber Consider the phrase "If Socrates is a man then he is 
mortal". This phrase is true given that Socrates is a mortal man, a mortal 
cat, or an immortal god. The only way it can be false is that Socrates is 
an immortal man. Similarly, the phrase "If Superman punched me then I would 
win the lottery" can only be false if Superman punched me and I did not win 
the lottery. Since Superman is not real, that can't happen, so the phrase 
"If Superman punched me then I would win the lottery" is true.

+fbiuzz No, it's not pretty hard to write a good story about a god. Nearly 
every single culture's folklore involves gods. People need to stop saying 
that shit, so that writers can go on and stop believing that shit, and just 
write the damn stories. Most of Superman's best stories are due to him 
exhibiting godlike powers: All-Star Superman, the Death and Return of 
Superman, Kingdom Come, the 90s JLA series, etc.

The fluctuating power levels allow for a wider variety of stories, and 
besides it's not like the different power levels all share in the same 
continuity. The Superman who once chained several planets together and 
pulled them by himself is not in the same continuity as the Superman who 
needed help pulling ONE planet, who is not in the same continuity as the 
Superman who had trouble lifting an oil rig.

captions.text:
Hey Vsauce I'm Jake and if you've played Injustice:
Gods Among Us, you know how awesome it is
to be Superman and punch people into space. But what if he were to hit you in real life?

What would happen if someone who is able to
lift 200 quintillion tons with one hand, power

the sun or, my favorite, punch dimensions
apart...were to punch you?

And this brings up an interesting idea: Superman
-- and really any fictional character -- is

only as powerful as the person writing them.
He has gone from being able to leap tall buildings

in a single bound to moving faster than the
speed of light. In this theory, no matter

how strong Superman is, there is one universal
law of physics he can't break--that nothing

with mass can achieve--travelling the speed
of light. So we will put him 1% below that

299,792,458 m/s limit at 99% the speed of
light.

So you're, unfortunately, in a fight with
the Man of Steel who, in this case, will not

restrain himself when hitting you. If his
fist has an average mass of 300 grams and

it's moving at 99% the speed of light, it
would have a total energy of about 190,000,000,000,000,000

joules. Which is equivalent to 45 Megatons
of TNT or over 2,800 times more powerful than
the nuclear bomb dropped on Hiroshima. Throwing just one punch at near the

speed of light with that much energy would
burn around 45,400,000,000,000 calories or
almost 82 billion Big Macs.

Now you have one of the largest bombs ever, condensed
into a fist, and aimed at your face. What
happens when Superman releases that punch?

This is when it gets incredibly cool...or
incredibly hot since the energy being released

by Superman's fist would be around 80,000,000,000,000
Kelvin, which is 5 million times hotter than
the core of our sun.

It takes about 1 centisecond for the light
that hits your retina to then be processed

by the brain, so since the punch is travelling
at near the speed of light, it would only

take 3.4 Nanoseconds for the fist to get to
you. So you literally wouldn't see it coming.

But what we can see is that from the fist's
perspective, since it is moving at an amazing

296 million meters a second, all of time is
practically frozen. The particles in the air,

the oxygen and nitrogen, are just suspended
in time. And Superman's hand hits them with

such energy that it creates nuclear fusion.
Gamma rays explode from every collision and

create an explosion unlike any the Earth has
ever seen. A giant fireball engulfs the surrounding

area and a blast wave shoots out, shattering
windows, structures and rips trees out of

the ground. There might be fictional characters
with more powerful punches, but at this point,

when it comes to you still existing, it doesn't
matter...

Superman wouldn't only knock the wind out
of you, he would knock the atoms out of you.

His fist has pretty much become a particle
beam. At 7,000,000,000 electron volts it is

more powerful than the Jefferson Labs Particle
Accelerator in Virginia. The atoms that made

up you would be completely disintegrated,
liquified at the atomic level. You'd turn

into fundamental particles and quark-gluon
plasma which is what was created right after

the Big Bang. And from all of this energy,
new particles and anti-particles would form.

So out of your unfortunate destruction, something
new, something we might not have ever seen
before, could be created.

To visualize the explosion we can use Nuke
Map to see what a 45 megaton bomb would look

like in terms of sheer damage, but what we
can't really show is that the damage from Superman's

punch would look more like a traffic cone
with a beam shooting out from where his fist

landed, destroying everything in its path
and creating an explosion all around him.

It would leave a crater almost 1km in diameter
and 221 meters deep.

So how close could you or I come to having
'Superman's strength'? My friends at AsapSCIENCE

breakdown strength muscle growth and how superhuman
strength may be more attainable than ever
before.

Don't piss of Superman and as always, thanks
for watching.
